metadata.title: Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen over single-crystal cubic palladium on silica catalysts

Fig. 1 Reactions involved in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide. Fig. 2 TEM images of Pd cubes synthesized using different capping agents: (a) 10mmol of KBr (denoted by 17Pd), (b) 5mmol of KBr (denoted by 9Pd), (c) 0.1mmol of KBr+4.9mmol of KCl (denoted by 7Pd), and (d) HRTEM image and FFT pattern (inset) of a single 9Pd nanocube particle. Fig. 3 TEM images of Pd cubes impregnated on SiO2: (a) 17Pd/SiO2, (b) 9Pd/SiO2, and (c) 7Pd/SiO2. Fig. 4 XRD patterns of (a) 17Pd/SiO2, (b) 9Pd/SiO2, and (c) 7Pd/SiO2; squares and circles indicate the characteristic peaks of silica and Pd, respectively. Fig. 5 Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide, without addition of halide, using 17Pd/SiO2, 9Pd/SiO2, and 7Pd/SiO2 catalysts: (a) hydrogen conversion and hydrogen peroxide selectivity and (b) hydrogen peroxide productivity (Pd-weight-specific hydrogen peroxide production rate); reaction conditions: T, 20°C; P, 1 atm; time, 3h; total flow rate, 22mL/min; H2/O2, 1/10; reaction medium, 150mL of DI water mixture (20% ethanol, 0.03M H3PO4); weight of catalyst, 0.2g. Fig. 6 Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide, with addition of halide, over Pd cubes of different sizes supported on SiO2: (a) hydrogen conversion and hydrogen peroxide selectivity and (b) hydrogen peroxide productivity (Pd-weight-specific hydrogen peroxide production rate); reaction conditions: T, 20°C; P, 1 atm; time, 3h; total flow rate, 22mL/min; H2/O2, 1/10; reaction medium, 150mL of DI water mixture (20% ethanol, 0.9mM KBr, 0.03M H3PO4); weight of catalyst, 0.2g. Fig. 7 TEM images of (a) the used 9Pd/SiO2 and (b) the used 9Pd (both after reaction): (inset in (b): the HRTEM image of the used 9Pd). Fig. 8 XRD patterns of the used catalysts: (a) 17Pd/SiO2, (b) 9Pd/SiO2, and (c) 7Pd/SiO2. The squares and circles indicate the characteristic peaks of silica and Pd, respectively. Table 1 Surface elemental composition of 9Pd/SiO2 (EDX analysis). N O Si Br Pd Atomic percentage (%) 3.4 11.8 15.7 0 69.1 Table 2 Fractions of surface atoms on Pd nanocubes of different sizes. Atom number ratios in percent a 7Pd (cube size=7nm) 9Pd (cube size=9nm) 17Pd (cube size=17nm) Number of terrace atoms on the {100} surface b /Total number of atoms in a single fcc cube (%) 14.52 11.27 6.44 Number of corner/edge atoms on the {100} surface/Total number of atoms in a single fcc cube (%) 0.83 0.48 0.14 Number of corner/edge atoms/Number of atoms on the {100} surface (%) 5.76 4.28 2.30 a Each number was calculated based on the reference [23]. b The atoms on the edges and corners (of the surface) were not counted. Table 3 Pd loss in Pd/SiO2 catalysts after reaction (ICP analysis). Catalyst Pd loss (%) 7Pd/SiO2 67 9Pd/SiO2 55 17Pd/SiO2 77 Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen over single-crystal cubic palladium on silica catalysts Seongmin Kim a Dae-Won Lee a ⁎⁎ Kwan-Young Lee a b ⁎ a Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Korea University, 145 Anam-ro, Seoul 136-713, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Korea University 145 Anam-ro Seoul 136-713 Republic of Korea b Green School, Korea University, 145 Anam-ro, Seoul 136-713, Republic of Korea Green School, Korea University 145 Anam-ro Seoul 136-713 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 2 3290 3299; fax: +82 2 926 6102. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 2 3290 3727; fax: +82 2 926 6102. Graphical abstract The activities of Pd metal catalysts for direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis are influenced by the morphological and crystallographic properties of the Pd species. We prepared {100}-facet-enclosed Pd nanocubes of uniform shape, size, and crystallinity using an aqueous colloidal method. The nanocube size was adjusted, without affecting the shape, by changing the composition of the halide-ion capping agent. The Pd nanocubes were impregnated on silica, and tested as a catalyst in direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis. The {100} Pd facet catalyzed hydrogen peroxide formation but promoted side reactions, decreasing hydrogen peroxide selectivity; the selectivity was improved by blocking active sites on the {100} facet with bromide ions. Keywords Nanocubes Palladium Nanocatalyst Hydrogen peroxide Direct synthesis 1 Introduction Face-centered cubic (fcc) noble metal nanoparticles (Pd, Au, Pt, etc.) of specific shapes and sizes can be synthesized using colloidal methods, in which metal precursors are dispersed over a homogeneous surfactant solution and precipitated to metallic crystallites with control of the nucleation and growth rates [1–4]. There are many papers in the literatures on the roles of synthetic reagents such as reducing agents, stabilizers (including surfactants), capping agents, and etchants in determining the sizes and/or shapes of nanoparticles [1–7]. The shape of an fcc nanoparticle determines the facet exposed on its surface: cubic, octahedral, and decahedral nanoparticles are enclosed by {100}, {111}, and {110} facets, respectively [1,8]. Truncated cubic and truncated octahedral nanoparticles are enclosed by {111}/{100} facets in different ratios [9]. In general, the formation of multi-facet-enclosed nanoparticles is thermodynamically favored compared with single-facet-enclosed nanoparticles. To promote the formation of nanoparticles enclosed by a single facet, it is necessary to use a specific capping agent in the synthesis. It is known that bromide ions and citric acid preferentially promote the formation of {100} and {111} facets, respectively [1]. The facet determines the way in which metal atoms are arranged on a surface, so the nanoparticles enclosed by a specific facet (i.e., nanoparticles of a specific shape) exhibit unique catalytic properties and activities. For example, cubic Pd nanoparticles are more active than octahedral Pd nanoparticles in electrocatalytic oxygen–reduction reactions [10]. In the hydrogenation of benzene with Pt catalysts, the selectivities for cyclohexane and cyclohexene depend on the shape of the Pt particles [11]. Cyclohexane and cyclohexene are both produced on cuboctahedal Pt nanoparticles, but only cyclohexane is produced on cubic nanoparticles; these selectivities are the same as those exhibited by Pt {111} and Pt {100} model surface. It is therefore highly anticipated to use shape-controlling techniques in the design of noble metal catalysts, especially those for structure-sensitive reactions of high industrial value. In this work, we studied the use of cubic Pd nanoparticles (i.e., Pd nanocubes) in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide by oxidation of hydrogen with molecular oxygen. This reaction is an environmentally benign and economically attractive alternative to the commercial process used for producing hydrogen peroxide (Riedl–Pfleiderer or anthraquinone process). It is usually progressed in a three phase (gas–liquid–solid) reactor where the gases (hydrogen and oxygen) are fed to the aqueous slurry of catalyst. The hydrogen peroxide is formed on the solid catalyst and accumulated in the aqueous phase in which acid (phosphoric or sulfuric acid) is dissolved to protect hydrogen peroxide from dissociation. On the catalyst, the hydrogen peroxide formation (Route I in Fig. 1 ) competes with several side reactions, that is, the combustion of hydrogen (Route II in Fig. 1) and dissociation and hydrogenation of hydrogen peroxide (Route III and IV in Fig. 1). Hence, the selectivity of hydrogen peroxide is an important index along with H2 conversion for evaluating catalytic activities in direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis. Palladium-based catalysts are the most widely used and studied catalysts for this reaction [12–22]. The morphological and crystallographic properties of the Pd metal species are one of the critical factors governing the catalytic activity. Menegazzo et al. reported that a less energetic (or less defective) Pd surface, which adsorbs oxygen without dissociation, is necessary for hydrogen peroxide production [13]. Edwards et al. studied Pd–Au alloy catalysts and suggested that addition of a small amount of Au changed the physical or electronic structure of Pd in a way that increased hydrogen peroxide selectivity [14]. Zhou et al. claimed that the {110} facet of Pd has a desirable atomic configuration for hydrogen peroxide production, whereas the {100} and {111} facets promote water-producing side reactions, suppressing the selectivity of hydrogen peroxide [15]. However, there are different opinions as to which is the most desirable Pd facet for the synthesis of hydrogen peroxide. Rossi et al. asserted that the {100} Pd surface is more active than the polycrystalline surface for hydrogen peroxide production [16]. According to the density functional theory study by the {111} facet is the most suitable among the low-index facets of Pd, such as {100}, {111}, and {110}, for the production of hydrogen peroxide [17]. In most of these studies, the catalysts contained the palladium species which were polycrystalline or alloy, so the results gave no information on how the morphological properties of the single-shape Pd crystals are related to its catalytic activity. Some studies used a Pd disk aligned with a single-crystal facet [16], and these gave valuable information regarding the intrinsic activity of a specific Pd facet, but inevitably ignored the influence of the properties of impregnated Pd metal, such as the particle size and interactions with the support material. Therefore, a systematic study of Pd catalysis investigating the catalytic activities of single-shape Pd nanocrystals, each of which is enclosed by its own crystallographic facet is needed [1]. Such information would be helpful in designing Pd-based catalysts for various applications, including hydrogen peroxide synthesis. In this study, we synthesized single-crystal Pd nanocubes enclosed by {100} facets, in an aqueous phase, using l-ascorbic acid as a reductant (to reduce metal cations to metal), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) as a stabilizer (to prevent nanoparticle agglomeration), and halide ions (Br− or Br− +Cl−) as a capping agent (to stabilize a specific facet on the Pd particle surface) [1,7]. The Pd nanocubes were impregnated on a silica support, and the catalytic activity of the silica-supported Pd nanocubes in the direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis was evaluated. In many cases, halide ions are added to the reaction to improve the selectivity of hydrogen peroxide [18,19]. The halide ions are adsorbed on the Pd surface and influence the electronic state of Pd, which leads to the suppression of side reactions, promoting the selectivity of hydrogen peroxide. The way in which halide ions influence the selectivity of hydrogen peroxide is probably characteristic of a specific Pd facet. We therefore examined the influence of halide ions on the catalytic activity of {100}-facet-enclosed Pd nanocubes for hydrogen peroxide production. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Pd nanocubes The Pd nanoparticle synthesis was based on the work of Lim et al. [1]. An aqueous solution (16mL) containing l-ascorbic acid (0.680mmol; Sigma–Aldrich), PVP (0.189mmol; molecular weight 55,000g/mol; Sigma–Aldrich), and a halide-ion capping agent (10mmol of KBr, 5mmol of KBr, or a mixture of 0.1mmol of KBr and 4.9mmol of KCl) was prepared. The solution was preheated at 80°C for 5min, and then Na2PdCl4 aqueous solution (63.8mM, 6mL) was added to the solution. Precipitates began to form and stirring was continued for 3h. The slurry was mixed with acetone in a volume ratio of 1:10 and the Pd nanoparticles were collected by centrifuging the slurry at 3500rpm for 10min. The collected nanoparticles were washed several times with deionized (DI) water. 2.2 Immobilization of Pd nanocubes on silica The collected Pd nanoparticles were dispersed in deionized water (4mL). The Pd slurry was impregnated on amorphous silica gel (4g, specific surface area=291m2/g, pore volume=1.105cm3/g; Sigma–Aldrich) and the vacuum dried at 60°C overnight. 2.3 Characterization For transmission electron microscopy (TEM), the sample was dispersed in ethanol, and dropped on a Cu grid and dried under ambient air conditions. TEM images were obtained using a field-emission TEM microscope (Tecnai G2 F30 ST, FEI), operated at 300kV. The average size, aspect ratio, and production yield of the nanocubes were determined by measuring 120 particles in the TEM image. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a D/MAX-2500/PC diffractometer (Rigaku), operated at 40kV and 200mA with Cu Kα1 radiation (λ =1.5406Å). The loading amount of Pd on the silica was analyzed using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES; iCPA-6300 Duo, Thermo Scientific). 2.4 Catalytic activity tests: direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide The catalytic activity tests were performed using the reaction conditions described in our previous paper [20]. The reactions were carried out at 20°C and atmospheric pressure for 3h. The catalyst loading was 0.2g. The reaction medium was 150mL of an ethanol (20%)–DI water solution (0.03M) of phosphoric acid, with or without 0.9mM KBr. The total gas flow rate was 22mL/min, and the hydrogen/oxygen ratio was 1/10. The hydrogen peroxide concentration was measured using iodometric titration. The concentration of hydrogen was measured using a gas chromatograph (Younglin, ACME6000) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and a Carbosieve SII-packed column. 3 Results and discussion TEM images of the synthesized Pd nanoparticles are shown in Fig. 2 (a)–(c); the halide-ion capping agent contents were 10mmol of KBr, 5mmol of KBr, and 0.1mmol of KBr+4.9mmol of KCl, respectively. The average aspect ratios of the Pd particles were 1.2, 1.1, and 1.2, respectively, confirming that the particles were nearly cubic. For each sample, the yield of cubes (the number of cubes per total number of particles) was over 95%. It was observed that the capping agent content influenced the average size of the Pd cubes. In Fig. 2(a)–(c), the average widths of the Pd cubes were 17, 9, and 7nm, respectively; these samples are denoted by 17Pd, 9Pd, and 7Pd. According to Lim et al., Br− ions preferentially chemisorb onto the {100} surfaces of Pd, and the capping effect promotes the formation of nanocubes and nanobars, which are enclosed by {100} facet [1]. Also, the halide ions influence the dimension of Pd nanoparticles. Halide ions form ligand complexes with Pd cations and as a result, slow down the reduction rate of Pd precursor [7]. It is therefore possible to control the precursor reduction rate by adjusting the concentration of halide ion. If the precursor reduction rate increases (by decreasing halide ion concentration), the number of seeds in the nucleation step increases, which leads to the formation of smaller nanoparticles [7]. From our results, it is expected that the decrease of KBr amount from 10 to 5mmol led to the increase of precursor reduction rate, resulting in a decrease in the particle size (from 17 to 9nm). However, when the amount of KBr was decreased to below 5mmol, the capping effect disappeared and spherical Pd particles were produced. As an alternative, Cl−, which coordinates more weakly than Br− to Pd2+ [7], was mixed with Br−, and the mixture (0.1mmol of KBr+4.9mmol of KCl) was used as a capping agent. The particle size decreased to 7nm, with retention of the cubic shape (Fig. 2(c)). Fig. 2(d) shows high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of a single Pd cube (9Pd) and the corresponding fast Fourier transform (FFT) pattern (inset). Continuous fringes along the axis are clearly seen, with an interval of 0.195nm, which is consistent with the d-spacing of the {200} facet of the Pd lattice (JCPDS #46-11043). The square symmetry of the FFT pattern indicates that the Pd nanocube was a perfect fcc crystal. Fig. 3 presents TEM images of the Pd nanocubes impregnated on a silica support (17Pd/SiO2, 9Pd/SiO2, and 7Pd/SiO2). The images show that the morphologies and sizes of the Pd nanocubes were well preserved after impregnation. The energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) data of 9Pd/SiO2 was presented in Table 1 . Br− ions, which were used in the synthesis of Pd nanoparticles, were completely removed from catalyst surface after preparation of the catalyst. The Pd loading was estimated to be approximately 1.2wt.% for the three impregnated catalysts (ICP-OES analysis). The XRD patterns of the three catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . The broad peak at 22° corresponds to amorphous silica. The peaks at 40.1°, 46.6°, and 68.1° correspond to the {111}, {200}, and {220} planes of the fcc Pd lattice (PDF: 46-1043), and they decrease in intensity as the size of the Pd nanocubes decreases. The activities of impregnated catalysts in direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide were tested. First, the reactions were performed without addition of Br− ions (KBr); the results are shown in Fig. 5 . As the size of the impregnated Pd nanocubes decreased (17Pd/SiO2 → 9Pd/SiO2 → 7Pd/SiO2), the hydrogen conversion increased and the hydrogen peroxide selectivity decreased (Fig. 5(a)). Eventually, the productivity of hydrogen peroxide (i.e., the Pd-weight-specific hydrogen peroxide production rate) decreased with decreasing Pd nanocube size (Fig. 5(b)). These results imply that as the size of the Pd nanocubes decreased, side reactions such as combustion of hydrogen (to water), and decomposition of hydrogen peroxide were promoted. It is known that the side reactions are promoted by dissociation of OO bonds in the oxygen and hydrogen peroxide molecules [14,22]. The dissociated oxygen reacts with hydrogen and forms a hydroxyl species (OH), which is hydrogenated to water. The dissociation of OO bonds in hydrogen peroxide forms OH directly, and the OH is also hydrogenated to water. The hydrogen peroxide selectivity of a Pd-based catalyst therefore depends on how the active phase of Pd promotes the dissociation of OO bonds [14,22]. According to Wang et al.’s simulation results, at low surface coverage, there is hardly any molecular oxygen on the Pd {100} surface, and it is easily dissociated to atomic oxygen [22]. Table 2 lists the estimated fractions of {100} surface atoms in a single Pd cube for 7Pd, 9Pd, and 17Pd. It was assumed that each cube was an ideal, perfect fcc crystal, and free of surface defects; the formula proposed by Hardeveld and Hartog [23] was used for the calculations. As the data in the first row of Table 2 show, the fraction of {100} terrace atoms increased as the Pd nanocube size decreased. Because we have observed hydrogen peroxide selectivity (and productivity) decreased with the decrease of Pd nanocube size, the data implies that the {100} facet promotes the dissociation of OO bonds. It is also known that oxygen molecules are dissociated more effectively on the corner and edge atoms of Pd [24]. The data in the second row of Table 2 show that the fraction of corner/edge Pd atoms increases with decreasing Pd cube size. However, if it is assumed that the cubes are perfectly crystalline and free of defects, the number of corner/edge atoms is only 2.30–5.76% of the atoms on the {100} facet (see the third row of Table 2). So, it is suggested that the OO bond dissociation progresses dominantly on the terrace atoms of {100} facet rather than on the corner/edge atoms. Therefore, we concluded that {100} facet of Pd nanocube catalyzes the formation of hydrogen peroxide, but promotes side reactions through OO bond dissociation at the same time. Reaction tests were also performed with the addition of Br− ions (0.9mM KBr) to the reaction medium; the results are shown in Fig. 6 . When Br− ions were involved in the reaction, the hydrogen conversion by each catalyst was suppressed, but the overall hydrogen peroxide selectivity was greatly improved. In addition, unlike the tests performed without addition of Br− ions, both hydrogen conversion and hydrogen peroxide selectivity increased with decreasing Pd nanocube size. In the case of 7Pd/SiO2 which contained the smallest Pd nanocube, the hydrogen peroxide selectivity increased by 40% in the presence of 0.9mM Br−. According to Liu and Lunsford, halide ions (Cl−) enhanced hydrogen peroxide selectivity by blocking Pd sites through adsorption and complex formation (PdCl4 2−), or by modifying the activity of Pd sites through long-range electronic interactions [18]. Either by blocking or electronic effects, the halide ions inhibit breaking of the OO bonds of oxygen and hydrogen peroxide on the Pd surface, thereby suppressing side reactions and increasing the hydrogen peroxide selectivity. However, the blocking by halide ions also impeded access of reactants to the active sites, which could lead to a decrease in hydrogen conversion [19]. As already mentioned in the section on Pd nanocube preparation, Br− ions strongly adsorb on the {100} facet of Pd [1]. It is suggested that Br− ions adsorbed strongly on the {100} surfaces, inhibited hydrogen conversion and simultaneously suppressed the dissociation of OO bonds, leading to improved hydrogen peroxide selectivity. The used 9Pd/SiO2 catalyst and 9Pd nanocubes (9Pd nanocubes were directly used as the catalyst for the synthesis of hydrogen peroxide) were analyzed by TEM to verify whether the shape and morphology of Pd cubes were maintained or not after reaction. The results are presented in Fig. 7 . The Pd nanocubes immobilized on silica still maintained their cubic shape after reaction (Fig. 7 (a)). The used 9Pd nanocubes maintained their cubic shape too (Fig. 7 (b)). The HRTEM image (the inset in Fig. 7 (b)) showed that the lattice fringe of a used 9Pd nanocube was 0.195nm, which corresponded to the {100} facet of fcc Pd. If Pd had been chemically leached from the cube particles, the shape of particles would have changed from cube to other ones. Thus, it was indirectly concluded that the prepared Pd nanocubes are stable against chemical leaching under our reaction condition (0.03M of H3PO4). The XRD patterns of the used Pd/SiO2 catalysts were presented in Fig. 8 . All the used catalysts had characteristic peaks of metallic Pd (PDF:46-1043) at 40.1°, 46.6°, and 68.1° PdO was not detected in all the catalysts. It matches well with the TEM result (Fig. 7) that the Pd nanocubes had {100} lattice distance of a metallic Pd. Thus, it proved that Pd cubes were not oxidized by hydrogen peroxide during the reaction. However, the Table 3 showed that the large quantity of Pd was lost after reaction. But as we discussed with the TEM results (Fig. 7), it is supposed that the loss of Pd was not caused by chemical leaching. Rather, it is expected that the Pd nanoparticles were physically detached from silica support. Thus, the further study on the technique for immobilization of Pd nanocubes is needed to reduce the loss of supported metal and improve its immobilization efficiency. 4 Conclusions The aqueous-phase synthesis of {100}-facet-enclosed Pd nanocubes was performed using l-ascorbic acid as a reductant, PVP as a stabilizer, and KBr or KBr+KCl as a capping agent. The KBr content determined the size of the Pd nanocubes. The nanocube size decreased with decreasing KBr concentration. Control of the cube size below 7nm, with retention of the cubic shape, was achieved using a mixture of KBr+KCl as the capping agent. The prepared Pd nanocubes were well impregnated on a silica support, without noticeable changes in nanocube sizes and shapes. In activity tests without the addition of Br− ions, exposure of the Pd {100} surface had a negative effect on the hydrogen peroxide selectivity, possibly as a result of promotion of OO bond dissociation. The addition of Br− ions enhanced the selectivity of hydrogen peroxide, but suppressed conversion of hydrogen, by partially blocking the active sites on the {100} Pd surface. During the reaction, Pd nanocubes maintained their initial cubic shape which is enclosed by {100} facet and chemical state of metallic Pd. coredata.dc:description: The activities of Pd metal catalysts for direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis are influenced by the morphological and crystallographic properties of the Pd species. We prepared {100}-facet-enclosed Pd nanocubes of uniform shape, size, and crystallinity using an aqueous colloidal method. The nanocube size was adjusted, without affecting the shape, by changing the composition of the halide-ion capping agent. The Pd nanocubes were impregnated on silica, and tested as a catalyst in direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis. The {100} Pd facet catalyzed hydrogen peroxide formation but promoted side reactions, decreasing hydrogen peroxide selectivity; the selectivity was improved by blocking active sites on the {100} facet with bromide ions.
coredata.dc:title: Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen over single-crystal cubic palladium on silica catalysts
